G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this matter concerns modification of a prior custody and parenting time judgment of the Bristol County Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this matter concerns modification of a prior custody and parenting time judgment of the Bristol County Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this matter concerns modification of a prior custody and parenting time judgment of the Bristol County Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court because the prior judgment was entered in this Court and the minor children reside within this Court’s jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Bristol County Probate and Family Court because the prior judgment was entered in this Court and the minor children reside within this Court’s jurisdiction.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody and parenting time determinations and modifications in Massachusetts.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion does apply a best-interests analysis, but only in the specific context of (1) initial custody determination between parents and (2) a removal request under G.L. c. 208, § 30. It does not purport to state that the best-interests standard governs all custody and parenting time determinations and modifications in Massachusetts in a categorical, across‑the‑board way. The key discussion is tied to interpreting “upon cause shown” in the removal statute, not to a universal rule for every type of custody/parenting-time proceeding.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not … be removed out of this commonwealth … unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The “best interests of the child” standard governs all custody and parenting time determinations and modifications in Massachusetts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly affirms that the best interests of the child is the governing standard for custody determinations under G.L. c. 209C, §10(a), and more generally states that this standard has long been used in Massachusetts for custody and visitation. However, it does not state that this standard governs *all* custody and parenting time determinations and *all* modifications in Massachusetts. Indeed, the court distinguishes between initial custody determinations (best interests) and modification proceedings under §20 (substantial change in circumstances), so using this case to claim a unitary best-interests standard for all determinations and modifications is overbroad.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865 … It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’).”

Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 20.raw_text: Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 209, 210–11 (1982)
Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 20.proposition: The Probate and Family Court has broad equitable authority to modify custody and parenting time when a significant change in the parties’ or children’s circumstances renders the existing judgment no longer consonant with the children’s best interests.
Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 20.support_reasoning: The opinion does address modification of custody based on a change in circumstances and the best interests of the child, but it does not describe or emphasize the Probate and Family Court’s “broad equitable authority.” Instead, the court constrains that authority, stressing the presumption of correctness of the original custody judgment and requiring an affirmative finding of a sufficiently significant change in circumstances before modification. The case is better authority for the necessity and magnitude of a change in circumstances standard, not for broad equitable power to modify parenting time whenever the existing judgment no longer serves the child’s best interests.
Delmolino v. Nance, 14 Mass. App. Ct. 20.relevant_excerpt: “For decades, it has been the law that the original judgment awarding custody to a parent is presumed to have been correct… and that before a judge can order a transfer of custody from one parent to another, he must affirmatively find that there is a relevant change in circumstances… In addition, ‘that change must be of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’… In sum, there is nothing in the record that shows any relevant change in circumstances that would justify the transfer of custody ordered in this case.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 265 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: A significant change in a parent’s work schedule that undermines the existing parenting time arrangement, particularly as to overnight care and supervision, may constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses changes in the mother’s work schedule, but only to say that even a ‘hectic’ work schedule, and the related need for childcare, did not warrant a custody modification and that later improvements in her schedule also did not justify a change. The court emphasizes that no material and substantial change occurred that would support modifying custody, and it reverses the trial judge’s modification order. Accordingly, the case stands for the opposite of the claimed proposition rather than supporting it.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification. Second, by the time of trial, the probate judge found that positive changes in the mother’s work schedule ‘allowed her to spend more time with the minor child.’… Thus, to the extent that changes in the mother’s work schedule did occur, they were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement.”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.proposition: A significant change in a parent’s work schedule that undermines the existing parenting time arrangement, particularly as to overnight care and supervision, may constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns modification of alimony and child support based on the payor’s financial circumstances (income, earning capacity, and assets). It does not address custody, parenting time, or any change in a parent’s work schedule affecting overnight care or supervision. The court’s discussion of “material change of circumstances” is confined to financial changes, so the case does not provide authority for the proposition about work-schedule changes justifying modification of parenting time orders.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment… A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered in a request for reduction of a support award. … However, while a substantial decrease in income or financial status may warrant a modification, such a decrease does not alone compel a modification.”

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 243–44 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions emphasize the importance of stability and predictability for children, while recognizing that “the passage of time and attendant changes in the life situation of the parties and the child” may require modification.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss that custody determinations must consider both the present and the probable future circumstances of the child and parents, but it does not emphasize “stability and predictability” in those terms, nor does it address modification of prior custody orders or the role of the passage of time as a basis for modification. The quoted proposition about “the passage of time and attendant changes in the life situation of the parties and the child” does not appear in this case, and the decision focuses instead on best-interests analysis at an initial custody determination, not on modifying an existing order. Thus, this case is not proper authority for that specific proposition.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ … ‘It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the [child] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future . . . .’ Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 403, quoting from Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939).”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Court must consider the totality of the circumstances, including the children’s ages, their need for a stable routine, the safety and quality of each parent’s care, and each parent’s ability to meet the children’s daily needs.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a custody decision must be based on all relevant factors bearing on the child’s welfare, and criticizes the lower court for not doing so. It directs the probate judge on remand to examine the relative advantages of each parental environment and to make subsidiary findings on specific contextual factors (such as the length of time in the current environment and its impact on the child’s well-being). While it does not list ages, routine, safety, and daily needs verbatim, it endorses a totality-of-circumstances, best-interests analysis that encompasses such considerations.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. … The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child. … On rehearing, the findings should examine the relative advantages of the respective parental environments. Findings also would be appropriate concerning (1) the length of time the child has been in her present environment… and (2) whether and in what respects that environment has been helpful or detrimental to the child’s well being.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.proposition: The Court must consider the totality of the circumstances, including the children’s ages, their need for a stable routine, the safety and quality of each parent’s care, and each parent’s ability to meet the children’s daily needs.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the overarching “welfare of the child” standard and the probate judge’s broad discretion; it does not articulate a requirement that the court consider the totality of the circumstances with the specific factors listed (ages, stable routine, safety and quality of care, and ability to meet daily needs). While the facts mention care by each parent and the child’s reactions, the court does not formulate or discuss a multi-factor test matching the claimed proposition. Thus, the case does not clearly establish the detailed principle asserted.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.proposition: The Court also has the authority to impose reasonable conditions on parenting time to safeguard the children’s welfare, including tailoring overnights to times when a parent is actually available and able to provide adequate supervision.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Smith v. McDonald is a concurrence focused on statutory interpretation and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a custodial parent to move back to Massachusetts. It does not discuss, endorse, or define the court’s authority to impose conditions on parenting time or to tailor overnights based on a parent’s availability or supervisory capacity. Instead, it emphasizes that the judge exceeded her authority by ordering relocation, so it does not provide support for the specific proposition about conditioning parenting time.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. … As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is ‘free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].’ … After paternity was established, the judge was obligated … to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a)…”

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234\u20.proposition: The Court also has the authority to impose reasonable conditions on parenting time to safeguard the children’s welfare, including tailoring overnights to times when a parent is actually available and able to provide adequate supervision.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the court’s power to limit or condition visitation based on the child’s best interests, but the specific proposition here is about tailoring overnights to times when a parent is actually available and able to supervise. Felton concerns religious-instruction-based restrictions on a noncustodial parent’s visitation and reverses such a restriction for lack of evidence of harm; it does not address scheduling, overnights, or conditions tied to a parent’s work hours or availability. Thus it provides general support for conditioning visitation to protect welfare, but not for the specific tailored-overnight concept stated in the proposition.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 234\u20.relevant_excerpt: “But the ‘best interests’ of the child are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds, the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents… It is often said that if accommodation appears necessary, that form should be sought which intrudes least on the religious inclinations of either parent and is yet compatible with the health of the child.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that the use of third‑party caregivers may be relevant to a child’s best interests, especially when it results in instability, insufficient supervision, or exposure to individuals not vetted by the other parent or the Court.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on domestic violence and its impact on a child in custody determinations, not on a parent’s use of third‑party caregivers or related instability or vetting concerns. The court’s analysis and holding require explicit findings about the effects of domestic violence on the child and on the appropriateness of custody and shared custody; it does not discuss third‑party care arrangements or supervision by non‑parents as a factor in the best‑interests analysis. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the specific proposition about third‑party caregivers.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.” (422 Mass. at 599–600).

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that the use of third‑party caregivers may be relevant to a child’s best interests, especially when it results in instability, insufficient supervision, or exposure to individuals not vetted by the other parent or the Court.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that the nature and consequences of a substitute caregiver arrangement (including instability in a foster home) are relevant to a child’s best interests. The court notes the disruptions in the foster home caused by changing foster children and explicitly approves the trial judge’s reliance on this in light of expert testimony that Hugo needed a consistent and predictable environment. However, the case does not squarely address “unvetted” third parties or supervision problems as a doctrinal point; its support is more inferential than explicit.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “As to his finding that Ms. L. derived her income from foster care, the judge appropriately took note of disruptions within the foster family that Hugo had experienced and might continue to experience as foster children enter and leave Ms. L.’s home, a relevant matter in light of the expert testimony that Hugo needs a consistent and predictable home environment.”
